title: Jerry Remy returning to NESN’s Red Sox broadcast team - Red Sox
text:
Jerry Remy will be back on NESN’s Red Sox telecasts for a 29th season.
The network announced Thursday night that Remy, who has been part of team’s television broadcasts since 1988, has renewed his contract and will remain the primary color analyst in 2016, working at least 100 games.
“Jerry remains one of the most beloved color analysts in all of baseball,” said Sean McGrail, NESN’s president and CEO, in a statement. “We are thrilled to have him continue as the cornerstone of our broadcast. His insights and perspective on the Red Sox organization and the players make him one of the best analysts in the game.”
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Remy’s workload in 2016 will be fewer games than he has usually broadcast in a season in which he did not miss time for health reasons or personal matters. Dennis Eckersley and Steve Lyons are also expected to serve as color analysts for a number of games next season. The broadcast will feature a three-man booth for some games, with Eckersley or Lyons joining Remy and O’Brien.
Remy will be joined by a new partner in the booth. Dave O’Brien, who spent nine seasons on the Red Sox’ radio broadcasts on WEEI, is replacing longtime play-by-play voice Don Orsillo in the booth. The move caused significant backlash when news broke in late August that NESN did not intend to bring Orsillo back.
Orsillo, who formed a popular tandem with Remy for 15 years, has since joined the San Diego Padres’ broadcast team.
“NESN and the Red Sox have been very good to me over the years and I hope to continue for a long period of time what I consider to be the best job in the world of broadcasting,” said Remy in a statement. “I also look forward to welcoming my new play-by-play partner Dave O’Brien to the NESN team.”
Remy, who turns 63 in November, has been associated with the Red Sox organization for 37 years—eight as a player, one as a minor league coach, and the past 28 as a NESN broadcaster.
